results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film features vintage cars departing on a Veteran Car Rally that took place between London and Brighton, with models including Clément-Bayard, Fiat and Métallurgique cars from the 1900s and 1910s.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 two men working on a Clément-Bayard car with burgundy leather interior
00:00:16:00 two men driving a cream-coloured Fiat car
00:00:52:00 close up of the front of a red and black Métallurgique model
00:01:26:00 the departure of a green 1912 Rover
00:01:52:00 two men in an open red 1905 Itala, with cover over their legs
00:03:35:00 a man and woman in a red 1916 Ford T

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 122]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the family at the New South Wales coastal town of Eden, in 1938.

Opens with shots of small, masted boats in harbour (at Eden, New South Wales). One of the boats – with four men in it – is moving out of harbour under engine power.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 a pier, with vehicular rails running along it and a small two-chimneyed ship moored alongside. A small masted vessel is being prepared for launching
00:00:43:00 close-up of a man striding through the camera’s field of vision, then the camera pans slowly over the sea and coastal landscape
00:01:28:00 a bush-fringed road, with a parked car and a man sitting nearby (with back to camera). The camera lingers on the surrounding bush and hills, with the sea visible in the background. This sequence appears to be shot from a vantage point further inland than the earlier coastal scenes
00:01:57:00 two people are standing at the base of a tall building; the camera pans up the structure to show the ‘battlements’ at its top. This is ‘Boyd’s Tower’, a 23 metre structure built in 1847 by the ex-Scottish entrepreneur Ben Boyd, intended as a lighthouse, but never commissioned.
00:02:20:00 entire tower photographed from a slight distance; the full structure can be seen above the surrounding bush
00:02:37:00 same man who appeared earlier in the footage and a woman wearing riding jodhpurs are standing on a rise overlooking the water as the camera pans past them across the scene of bush and sea
00:03:06:00 same man and woman – accompanied by an older woman – are strolling through a park or garden above the coast, looking away from the camera. A dog is frolicking around them, and a horse is grazing nearby.
00:03:24:0 same man walking along a rise, looking away from the camera at the sea and headlands below him. The camera tracks him as he walks further away from it, looking back over his shoulder occasionally.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a collection of scenes including a QANTAS plane leaving the airport, a group of family and friends in the backyard of a suburban home, dressed for a celebration, and the Malinses’s Bedford camper van.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a group of kangaroos in grassy parkland
00:00:12:00 close-up of kangaroo with joey in her pouch
00:00:48:00 QANTAS airplane on the tarmac of Melbourne Airport, departing
00:01:21:00 a group of people on the lawn in a garden dressed in 1970s style clothing at what seems to be a celebration - great examples of 70s patterns and dress styles
00:01:55:00 close-up of man in white pants and pink check shirt with a pink ribbon flower attached to his back pocket digging in the garden bed; purple hydrangeas at the back of the bed and wishbone ferns at the front
00:02:10:00 exterior of a suburban brick house with venetian blinds and pot plants
00:02:19:00 a man drives a two-toned green Morris van out of the driveway
00:02:35:00 George and Sybil Malins with their Bedford camper van in a campground

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 121]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

Selected highlights (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:02:00 (upside down footage) caged orangutan at Zoo eating an ice cream
00:00:15:00 entrance to Melbourne Zoo
00:00:20:00 visitor hands food to a white-cheeked gibbon through cage fence
00:00:29:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John picnic on lawn, with the Taggart family
00:00:45:00 children ride the open-carriage train, ‘Zoo Spirit of Progress’ written on side of driver’s car (a reference to Victorian Railways premier express train from Melbourne to Albury)
00:01:07:00 children riding on an Indian Elephant
00:01:15:00 horse performing tricks for audience, balancing on a see-saw, riding and bucking in the arena with a baboon (possibly a hamadryas baboon) on back
00:01:40:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John with Mabel Malins (Nana) having a picnic with fire next to river, great shots of family members eating and smiling, at Healesville Sanctuary
00:02:40:00 Children play in yard. One boy wearing an ‘indian’ costume rides a tricycle; another boy rides a rocking horse; two girls push prams with dolls. Christmas morning at Rathmines Road, Hawthorn.
00:03:20:00 children and mother in caravan trailer, portable radio, bicycle and a 1940s Chevrolet Utility vehicle (Ute)
00:03:48:00 road sign ‘Anglesea – please slow down’
00:04:09:00 ‘Great Ocean Road’ Memorial Arch
00:04:25:00 road sign ‘Lorne – please slow down’
00:04:28:00 children walking in water and climbing on rocks at the beach
00:05:02:00 Sybil and girl standing next to road sign ‘Wye River’ at bridge
00:05:11:00 boy playing with toy boat in water
00:05:17:00 group of children paddling a yellow inflatable dinghy
00:05:51:00 John holding a small fish that he caught
00:05:59:00 gathering of families, playing games on beach
00:06:29:00 two children in bath, Helen and John
00:07:00:00 family, including Mabel Malins, celebrating Helen’s sixth birthday with cake at dining table
00:07:25:00 family in snow with sled, having a snowball fight at Lake Mountain
00:08:35:00 Helen and John at horse-riding school on country road. A man and a boy pass by standing on the back of a flatbed ute.
00:08:58:00 children ride in a horse drawn cart with a crop harvest (possibly corn)

results.description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Titled Walking to School.
This could possibly be an Eaglehawk Primary School Production.

This narrative film follows the eventful journey of a young school boy as he walks to school along a country road. On the way he is joined by school friends and we see their encounters with a variety of native Australian Wildlife. They see lace monitor tracks and follow them to where the monitor is scaling a tree. They also find a possum and an echidna. The film shows various closeups of the animals and the children’s faces as they squint and shield their eyes from the sun.

The children cross a wooden bridge where they meet an old man carrying a swag and a billy. The man gathers the children around him and reads a story to them called “The Bear”. The film then shows us the story as it is being told. It is a tale of a young girl who is very poor, very dirty and very sad. One day she finds a toy koala which brings her great joy. Excitedly she tries to show her Koala to other school children who are playing games in the school yard. They ridicule her and throw sticks at her. She runs away and falls on the grass where she drifts off to sleep. She dreams that she is rescued by a fairy Godmother who transforms her into a very clean girl in a beautiful dress! During this sequence we see good examples of Super 8 “special effects” as the fairy works her magic on the other children, transforming them into characters in fancy dress. We see these children playing circle games and closeups of their faces. Eventually the poor girl wakes up to find a kind school boy standing over her. He helps her to her feet, takes her hand and leads her to join his other friends. Together the group skip happily all the way to school along a country road.

This film shows good examples of children’s fashion, games and faces. We also see footage of houses and streets of the time.

Selected Highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 Title card ‘Walking to School’
00:00:30:00 Goanna climbing tree
00:02:23:00 Echidna
00:03:45:00 Kids story time reading from ‘The Bear’

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film contains snippets of scenes from travels around Victoria. Firstly the Hume Dam (formerly Hume Weir) which is a major dam across the Murray River in New South Wales. Constructed between 1919 and 1936 and involving hydro-power as well as flood mitigation and irrigation, the Hume Dam would have been a major attraction at the time, the 1940s. There are also some scenes of the family children during what seems to be a stop along the way.

This very short black and white film is faded throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:24:00 a man in suit and hat clambering over large boulders and looking out at a view
00:00:45:00 the spillway drains at the Hume Dam
00:01:05:00 children smiling at the camera while standing near a car
00:01:17:00 one of the children holds what might be a small rabbit or possum

results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film captures two cake cuttings at two occasions. One is the 21st birthday party for a young woman in the family and the other her engagement celebration.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 happy guests surround a very happy and smiling young woman ass cuts a decorated party cake
00:00:49:00 the young woman and her young man kiss, hug and smile in among the guests and then turn to the camera to show off her engagement ring
00:01:13:00 another cake cutting at another occasion with the same couple
00:01:49:00 couples dancing
